-- CONTRIBUTORS

* Christopher Foley (Florida Atlantic University) - cfoley3@fau.edu
* Bijayita Thapa (Florida Atlantic University)  - bthapa@my.fau.edu

~-- SUMMARY --

The CIS5371-ElGamal project provides a module to encrypt / decrypt C++ strings using the ElGamal process  
and return a C++ string.  A command line input is provided to convert input text to encrypted form.  File names 
may be provided to the command line and output will be directed to a file.  A help option is provided.

A series of Eclipse generated and subsequently modified makefiles are provided for product development.

For a full description of the module, examination of the code is recommended.

To submit bug reports and feature suggestions, or to track changes:
  cfoley3@fau.edu


-- REQUIREMENTS --

Gnu Make, gcc

* This project uses CryptoPP.  Specifically, the large integer and random number generation modules.  The PnG (Prime and Generator) 
is also used to generate a prime number of varying size and an appropriate generator for the cyclic field.  The following bit sizes 
were explicitly tested (32, 128, 256, 512, 1024, 4096).

* The current release can not split messages into multiple buffers for encryption.  That is the responsibility of the driver
function.  

* Encrypting a message longer (in bits) than the prime number key, will result in message truncation.

-- INSTALLATION –

* The following files are provided in this release package:
   - ElGamal.h – header file required for use of the ElGamal.cpp module
   - ElGamal.cpp – ElGamal Algorithm Implementation for (de/en)cryption.
   - CIS5371Driver.cpp – program to trigger ElGamal functions, accepts commands as flags
                     and identifies text or files to encrypt.
   - README.TXT – this file



* it is recommended that the files be copied to a directory and make be used to build.

* WARNING:  Use of the -O option with the GCC compiler is discouraged.  Code Optimization 
with levels -O1, -O2, and -O3 have been observed to produce errors in Encryption.  No 
encryption errors have been observed with code optimization with -O0 (default or no optimization) 
or -Os (optimize for size) set during the build process.

* WARNING: Code assumes access to 64-bit long long int provided with C++ (2011).

* LibCryptoPP is resuired.
.  
-- CONFIGURATION --

* Configuration is by the command line options.  The following syntax may be used:

Usage: CIS5371Driver -h |  -e | -d [-k key_length -K file_name] -f MESSAGE_FILE 
	            -d  - decrypt MESSAGE_FILE, use of -d prohibits use of -e
	            -e  - encrypt MESSAGE_FILE, use of -e prohibits use of -d
	            -h  - display this message.  If use this must be the first parameter.
    	        -k key length, specified as a multiple of 2 greater than or equal to 128 bits, if omitted 128 bits is used
		        -K file_name  -file containing public key, generator and generated parameter. \".pub\" is appended for public key.
		           \".key\" is appended for private key. if file_name does not exist keys will be generated 
	            -f MESSAGE_FILE fully qualified path of file to encrypt.
		           use of the MESSAGE_FILE will result in the output being directed to MESSAGE_FILE.out.
		           MESSAGE_FILE will be broken into n byte chunks where n is the minimum number of bytes needed to store the key
		           output file will be n byte chunks containing a generated key and cipher text separated by a semicolon (;)\n

-h, -e or -d is required.

If a file is specified, the output will be to a file having the same name as the input with ".out" appended to the 
file name (e.g. message file of a.in will result in a file of a.in.out).

-- CUSTOMIZATION --

* 
-- TROUBLESHOOTING --

* 

-- FAQ --

Q: How do I know it works.

A: Use the test program test.cpp. The first test was the example shown in the book "Handbook of Applied Cryptography".  The second test
was to encode/decode the C++ string "\x01".  The only failure is encrypting an decrypting the string "\0".  The 
test program should produce the following output (key size: 4096 bits, breaks in line inserted for readability data displayed in decimal
and hexadecimal form): 

[chris@euclid Debug]$ ../Release/test
Begin B/A tests
TestB: P=935h
       G=2h
       Q=4a1h
       X=0h
TestA: P=935h
       G=2h
       Q=4a1h
       X=0h
Plaintext  :
Ciphertext :596h ; 824h
Plainertext:
plaintext:[] ?= plainertext:[]
decrypt match
Begin Bob/Alice tests
Bob: P=9199112326012953390727540744584072847889714933655537251294097318610448509486272000072963311666227022601208138454710355448
16293401980282658399128913631105538514174891727759091747135691908645716304114164582662107049394613615501345372993637118625595527

Q: How do you know this works.

A: 1) See the first question.  The first test is an example from the text.
